qas.question: What are the two major subtypes of T cells?

answers.text: killer T cell and the helper T cell
killer T cell and the helper T cell
the killer T cell and the helper T cell

qas.question: What kind of T cells have the purpose of modulating the immune response?
Killer T cells can only recognize antigens coupled to what kind of molecules?
Helper and regulatory T cells can only recognize antigens coupled to what kind of molecules?
What class of T cells recognizes intact antigens that are not associated with MHC receptors?
What cells do not carry receptor molecules?
What do T cells recognize before antigens have been processed?
How many subtypes of B cells exist?
How many roles do the types of B cell have?

plausible_answers.text: antigens coupled to Class I MHC molecules

qas.question: What do killer B cells recognize?

context: Both <b5_0>B cells and T cells<b5_0/> carry receptor molecules that recognize specific targets. T cells recognize a <b6_0>"non-self" target<b6_0/>, such as a pathogen, only after antigens (small fragments of the pathogen) have been processed and presented in combination with a "self" receptor called a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule. There are <b7_0>two<b7_0/> major subtypes of T cells: <a0_2>the <a0_0><a0_1>killer T cell and the helper T cell<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. In addition there are <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>regulatory<a1_1/> T cells<a1_2/><a1_0/> which have a role in modulating immune response. Killer T cells only recognize <b9_0>antigens coupled to <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>Class I MHC<a2_1/> molecules<b9_0/><a2_2/><a2_0/>, while helper T cells and regulatory T cells only recognize antigens coupled to <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>Class II MHC<a3_1/> molecules<a3_2/><a3_0/>. These <b8_0>two<b8_0/> mechanisms of antigen presentation reflect the different roles of the two types of T cell. A third, minor subtype are the <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>γδ<a4_1/> T cells<a4_2/><a4_0/> that recognize intact antigens that are not bound to MHC receptors.
